revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jay Chandrasekhar | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jayanth Jambulingam Chandrasekhar | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|4|9}} | birth_place = [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. | nationality = American | education = [[Lake Forest Academy]] | alma_mater = [[Colgate University]]
[[Loyola University Chicago|Loyola University]] {{small|(withdrew)}} | occupation = Actor, comedian, writer, director | years_active = 1996–present | known_for = [[Broken Lizard]] | children = 3 | relatives = [[Sendhil Ramamurthy]] (cousin) | website = {{URL|jay-chandrasekhar.com}} | spouse = {{marriage|Susan Clarke|2005}} }} '''Jayanth Jambulingam Chandrasekhar''' (born April 9, 1968) is an American comedian, film director, screenwriter, and actor. He is best known for his work with the [[sketch comedy]] group [[Broken Lizard]] and for directing and starring in the Broken Lizard films ''[[Super Troopers]]'', ''[[Club Dread]]'', and ''[[Beerfest]]''. He has also had several successes in directing feature films and television shows–notably ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]''–apart from the Broken Lizard troupe.{{cite news |last1=Rozeman|first1=Mark|title=Catching Up with Jay Chandrasekhar|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2013/05/catching-up-with-jay-chandrasekhar.html|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|date=14 May 2013}} == Early life and education == Chandrasekhar was born in [[Chicago]] to parents who lived in the adjacent suburb of [[Oak Park, Illinois]]. Both his father, Arcot Jambulingam "AJ" Chandrasekhar,{{cite web|title=Arcot Jamulingam Chandrasekhar - Illinois, Northern District (Eastern Division), Naturalization Index, 1926-1979|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/2H5J-4V8|website=[[FamilySearch]]|accessdate=30 August 2014}} and his mother, Hema Chandrasekhar,{{cite web|title=Hema Varadan Chandrasekhar - Illinois, Northern District (Eastern Division), Naturalization Index, 1926-1979|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/2H5J-4VD|website=[[FamilySearch]]|accessdate=30 August 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Sotonoff|first1=Jamie|last2=Gire|first2=Dann|title=Hinsdale's Jay Chandrasekhar: A Broken Lizard makes good - Chandrasekhar's suburban upbringing serves him well in Hollywood, he says|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20120807/entlife/708079946/|accessdate=29 August 2014|work=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]|date=7 August 2012}} are physicians of [[Tamil people|Indian Tamil]] origin and are originally from [[Chennai]].{{cite news|last1=Pais|first1=Arthur J.|title=Jay Chandrasekhar is big! |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/aug/05jay.htm|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[Rediff]]|date=5 August 2005}} The hospital where he was born, old [[Cook County Hospital]], was where his parents worked. Chandrasekhar has an older sister as well as a younger sister named Sandy Chandrasekhar, who is a lawyer.{{cite web|title=Sandhya P. Chandrasekhar|url=http://www.lw.com/people/sandhya-chandrasekhar|website=[[Latham & Watkins]]|accessdate=30 August 2014}} Chandrasekhar lived in Oak Park until his family moved farther west from Chicago to the suburb of [[Hinsdale, Illinois|Hinsdale]]. He graduated from the boarding high school [[Lake Forest Academy]]. He graduated from [[Colgate University]] with a major in European history and a minor in philosophy. During college he spent a semester at Chicago's [[Loyola University Chicago|Loyola University]]. == Career == === Broken Lizard comedy troupe === Chandrasekhar formed the troupe [[Broken Lizard]] with other former members of the comedy troupe, Charred Goosebeak, and [[Beta Theta Pi]], people he met during college at [[Colgate University]]. Chandrasekhar said he found his path to comedy after acting in high school and college. He did some [[open mic]] standup comedy work in Chicago and founded a sketch group called "Charred Goose Beak" at college. After moving to New York, the group was renamed Broken Lizard. Chandrasekhar began making shorts featuring the troupe, then made the self-funded movie ''[[Puddle Cruiser]]'' in 1996.{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=Brendan|title=Review: ‘Puddle Cruiser’|url=https://variety.com/1996/film/reviews/puddle-cruiser-1200447105/|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=27 October 1996}} The film made it into the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in 1997.{{cite web|title=Puddle Cruiser|url=http://history.sundance.org/films/1597/puddle_cruiser|website=[[Sundance Film Festival]]|accessdate=30 August 2014|year=1997}} Then in 2001, they made ''[[Super Troopers]]'' as an independent movie, which [[Harvey Weinstein]] helped to develop at [[Miramax Films]], but did not end up distributing.{{cite news|last1=Neumyer|first1=Scott|title=Altered State Police: An Oral History of 'Super Troopers'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/news/altered-state-police-an-oral-history-of-super-troopers-20140418|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=18 April 2014}} === Directing === In 2005, Chandrasekhar directed ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard (film)|The Dukes of Hazzard]]''.{{cite news|title=IGN Interviews Jay Chandrasekhar|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/08/04/ign-interviews-jay-chandrasekhar|accessdate=29 August 2014|work=[[IGN Entertainment|IGN]]|date=3 August 2005}}The [[action comedy film]] based on the 1970s [[The Dukes of Hazzard|American television series of the same name]] was the debut of [[pop music|pop]] [[singer]] [[Jessica Simpson]] as an actress. While financially successful, the film was met with negative reviews from critics. He has become an established television comedy director, directing episodes of ''[[Undeclared]],'' ''[[Happy Endings (TV series)|Happy Endings]],'' ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]],'' ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]],'' ''[[Psych (TV series)|Psych]]'' and ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]].'' He says that the earlier a director joins a show, the more impact he or she will have on its look and feel. In 2012, Chandrasekhar made the movie ''[[The Babymakers]].''{{cite news|last1=Chandrasekhar|first1=Jay|title=Things Have Changed Since Super Troopers|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jay-chandrasekhar/the-babymakers_b_1730768.html|accessdate=29 August 2014|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date=2 August 2012}} He directed several episodes of ''[[Blue Mountain State]]''. [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] released a pilot in the 2014 Amazon Original Series that he wrote and directed called ''Really''.{{cite web|title=Really 1 Season 2014|url=https://www.amazon.com/An-Inside-Look-At-Really/dp/B00MR9YENG/|website=[[Amazon.com|Amazon]]|accessdate=29 August 2014}} In June of 2018, the filmmaker revealed that he is in discussions with [[Marvel Studios]] to direct one of their upcoming movies.https://screenrant.com/jay-chandrasekhar-marvel-studios-mcu/ === Acting === Chandrasekhar guest starred alongside his cousin [[Sendhil Ramamurthy]] in a 2009 episode of ''[[Psych (TV series)|Psych]]'' which Chandrasekhar also directed. He appeared as the cab driver in the "Terror Taxi" skit from ''[[Jackass: Number Two]]''. He appeared as racist comedian Gupta Gupti Gupta in the episode "Basic Email Security" of ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]''. === Stand-up === Chandrasekhar often does stand-up comedy, sometimes touring with fellow Broken Lizard friends, [[Steve Lemme]] and [[Kevin Heffernan (actor)|Kevin Heffernan]].{{cite news|last1=Greenberg|first1=Ruth|title=‘Super Troopers’ star Jay Chandrasekhar slings jokes at the Arlington Cinema & Drafthouse|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/express/wp/2014/08/28/super-troopers-jay-chandrasekhar-slings-jokes-at-the-arlington-cinema-drafthouse/|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=28 August 2014}} His stand-up is a mix of jokes and stories, which are usually pretty dirty. == Personal life == Chandrasekhar has been married to actress Susan Clarke since 2005.{{cite news|title=The Jay Chandrasekhar File|url=http://www.khabar.com/magazine/chaitime/the_jay_chandrasekhar_file|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=Chai Time|date=January 2011}} They have three children, an older son and twins. Chandrasekhar's middle name, Jambulingam, is in honor of his grandfather, and is also his son's middle name. During an interview with [[Stephen Colbert]] in 2017, Chandrasekhar stated that the name Jambulingam translates literally in English as "large penis," however, it is intended "as a euphemism for power."{{cite web|title=Jay Chandrasekhar Hung Out (Carefully) With Willie Nelson|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cJjyJvjAP34|website=YouTube|accessdate=3 April 2017}} Chandrasekhar's cousin is the actor [[Sendhil Ramamurthy]], who played the role of [[Mohinder Suresh]] in the [[NBC]] superpower drama [[Heroes (TV series)|''Heroes'']] and also appeared in the Broken Lizard film ''[[The Slammin' Salmon]].'' On the pronunciation of his last name, Chandrasekhar says you pronounce it: "CHAN- DRAH- SAY- CAR."{{cite web|last1=Chandrasekhar|first1=Jay|last2=Chalke|first2=Sarah|title=AMA: I am Jay Chandrasekhar, joined by Sarah Chalke from the new Amazon pilot "Really" - ask us anything.|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/2fhysh/i_am_jay_chandrasekhar_joined_by_sarah_chalke/ck9dnq1|website=[[reddit]]|accessdate=28 September 2014|date=4 September 2014}} == Filmography == === Films === * 1996: ''[[Puddle Cruiser]]'' – Zach; director, writer * 1999: ''[[Los Enchiladas!]]'' - editor * 2001: ''[[Super Troopers]]'' – Arcot "Thorny" Ramathorn; director * 2004: ''[[Club Dread]]'' – Putman; director * 2005: ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard (film)|The Dukes of Hazzard]]'' – Campus Cop #1; director * 2006: ''[[Beerfest]]'' – Barry Badrinath; director * 2006: ''[[Jackass Number Two]]'' – Himself/Terror Taxi host * 2008: ''Held Up'' (TV movie) – director * 2009: ''[[I Love You, Man]]'' – Party Guest * 2009: ''[[The Slammin' Salmon]]'' – Nuts/Zongo * 2009: ''The 2 Bobs'' – Spam King * 2010: ''[[Broken Lizard Stands Up]]'' – self; director * 2012: ''[[The Babymakers]]'' - Ron Jon, director * 2012: [[Freeloaders (film)|''Freeloaders'']] * 2018: ''[[Super Troopers 2]]'' – director; co-writer === Television (as director) === * 2001-2002: ''[[Undeclared]]'' – "Hal and Hillary", "Hell Week", "Rush and Pledge" * 2003: ''[[Andy Richter Controls the Universe]]'' – "Saturday Early Evening Fever" * 2004: ''[[Oliver Beene]]'' – "Kissing Babies" * 2004: ''[[Cracking Up (TV series)|Cracking Up]]'' – "Grudge Match" * 2003-2004: ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' – "Justice is Blind", "Altar Egos", "Beef Consommé", "My Mother The Car" * 2007: ''[[Human Giant]]'' – "Ta Da", "Lil 9-11", "Let's Go" * 2006-2007: ''[[The Loop (U.S. TV series)|The Loop]]'' – "The Dutch", "CSI: Donut Idol Bowl", "The Rusty Trombone", "The Tiger Express" * 2008: ''[[Lipstick Jungle (TV series)|Lipstick Jungle]]'' – "Chapter 4: Bombay Highway", "Chapter 17: Bye, Bye Baby" * 2008-2009: ''[[Knight Rider (2008 TV series)|Knight Rider]]'' – 2008 TV series; "Knight of the Hunter" and "Fly by Knight" * 2010-2011: ''[[Blue Mountain State]]'' – "Superstition", "The Peak", "Riot", "Drunk Tank", "Marathon Monday" * 2008-2012: ''[[Psych (TV series)|Psych]]'' – "Let's Doo-Wop It Again", "Chivalry Is Not Dead... But Someone Is", "Bollywood Homicide", "The Greatest Adventure in the History of Basic Cable" * 2008-2012: ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]'' – "Chuck Versus the Ex", "Chuck Versus the Suburbs", "Chuck Versus the Living Dead", "Chuck Versus the Balcony", "Chuck Versus Sarah" * 2009-2012: ''[[Royal Pains]]'' – "The Hankover", "A Guest House Divided", "Hank and the Deep Blue Sea", "Am I Blue?" * 2010-2015: ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'' – "Mixology Certification", "Intro to Political Science", "Applied Anthropology and Culinary Arts", "The First Chang Dynasty", "Advanced Documentary Filmmaking", "Introduction to Teaching", "Basic Story", "Basic Email Security", "Basic RV Repair and Palmistry" * 2011-2012: ''[[Happy Endings (TV series)|Happy Endings]]'' – "The Girl with the David Tattoo", "Meet the Parrots", "You Snooze, You Bruise", "More Like Stanksgiving" * 2011-2012: ''[[Up All Night (TV series)|Up All Night]]'' – "First Night Away", "Baby Fever" * 2012: ''[[Warehouse 13]]'' – "No Pain, No Gain" * 2012: ''[[Animal Practice]]'' – "Dr. Yamamazing" * 2012: ''[[Ben & Kate]]'' – "Career Day" * 2014: ''Really'' – also wrote and produced * 2014-2018: ''[[New Girl (TV series)|New Girl]]'' – "Sister III", "The Crawl", "Jeff Day", "Mario", "The Cubicle" * 2015-2016: ''[[The Grinder (TV series)|The Grinder]]'' – "The Curious Disappearance of Mr. Donovan", "A System on Trial", "Full Circle" * 2016: ''[[Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (TV series)|Crazy Ex-Girlfriend]]'' – “When Will Josh See How Cool I Am?” * 2017: ''[[Fresh Off the Boat]]'' - "A League of Her Own" * 2018: ''[[The Mayor (TV series)|The Mayor]]'' - "The Lockdown" * 2018: ''[[Instinct (U.S. TV series)|Instinct]]'' - "Long Shot" === Television (as actor) === * 2004: ''[[The 100 Scariest Movie Moments]]'' (TV Special) - as himself * 2007: ''[[Attack of the Show]]'' – as co-host, April 16 and 18, 2007 * 2007: ''[[Welcome to the Parker]]'' – episode 1 * 2009: ''[[Psych (TV series)|Psych]]'' – episode: "Bollywood Homicide" – Jawaharlal 'Jay' Singh * 2012: ''[[Royal Pains]]'' – episode: "A Guesthouse Divided" – Jake * 2013: ''[[Call Me Crazy: A Five Film]]'' (TV Movie) – Joey * 2013: ''[[Franklin & Bash]]'' – episode: "Gone in a Flash" – JD Altero * 2014: ''Really'' * 2015: ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'' – episode: "Basic Email Security" – Gupta Gupti Gupta * 2016: ''[[Family Guy]]'' - episode: "[[Road to India (Family Guy)|Road to India]]" * 2018: ''[[Nailed It!|Nailed It]] -'' episode 6: "In Your Face!" - as guest judge * 2018: ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]'' - season 5, episodes 16 - as himself == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|0151540}} {{Jay Chandrasekhar}} {{Broken Lizard}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chandrasekhar, Jay}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:Male actors from Illinois]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American Hindus]] [[Category:American male screenwriters]] [[Category:American people of Indian Tamil descent]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American television directors]] [[Category:American film directors of Indian descent]] [[Category:American male writers]] [[Category:American male actors of Indian descent]] [[Category:Broken Lizard]] [[Category:Colgate University alumni]] [[Category:English-language film directors]] [[Category:Lake Forest Academy alumni]] [[Category:Male actors from Chicago]] [[Category:Film directors from Illinois]] [[Category:Asian-American film directors]]
